awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Real-time, Low Cost Point-and-Shoot 3D Camera
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project is aimed at developing a comprehensive software suite for 3D imaging. 3D imaging is the capture of physical shape and motion as digital data. The technology can be used to create special effects, take measurements in engineering, and automatically check product quality in factories. Current 3D imaging systems are often too expensive, too slow, or too inaccurate to provide viable commercial solutions. This project will develop new techniques for three areas within the broader topic of 3D imaging: reconstruction, inspection, and motion capture. The objective of the project is to develop fast software that can run on low-cost, commercially available sensors and computing hardware. The software will be designed to take advantage of new kinds of computer processors found in computers and mobile phones: heterogeneous processors. To provide high-quality results on this emerging computing platform, the project will develop new mathematical and software approaches.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will result from the introduction of low-cost, high performance 3D imaging tools to the marketplace. 3D printing is an example of the way in which reducing cost and making a technology easier to use can create entirely new applications and markets. The research objectives of this project will lead to 3D imaging products that are cheaper and easier to use than today's solutions. 3D imaging addresses large and growing markets in engineering, inspection, manufacturing, surveying, and product development. It can enhance these industries by reducing costs and saving time. Making the technology easier to use will allow it to be adopted more widely, cultivating new vocational skills and opportunities. An additional impact of this research will be to make 3D imaging accessible to researchers and professionals in new application areas such as medicine, consumer technology, and security systems.

por.por_cntn:
Lynx Laboratories Inc. is a 3D imaging company focused on problems in engineering and consumer tech. The company's platform provides fast and accurate acquisition of 3D models that capture the appearance and shape of real-world objects. These models can be used in engineering design, photography software, and 3D printing.

We used our NSF SBIR Phase 2 grant to develop next-generation 3D imaging technologies. We developed a new software for capturing the shape of real-world objects. The software is designed to work on new kinds of processors found on laptops and cellphones, and it is up to 40 times faster than technologies that have previously been avilable. We also used the grant to improve the the accuracy of mobile scanning. Based on the research conducted under the grant, our products can now be used free-hand, making them much easier for regular people to use. We also improved how our systems capture and display color. As a result, the models look as good to a consumer as they do to a professional engineer.

With the support of the SBIR Phase 2 Program, our company further developed our software platform. Extensions to the software platform include the ability to operate with 2D cameras. The company has since merged with Occipital, a leading 3D computer vision company. Software developed pursuant to the NSF Phase 2 grant has been further developed and integrated into Occipital's products as well as a licensed to 3rd party consumer technology companies.

The technologies developed under the grant have the potential to change many industries. Engineering professionals will be able to design much faster by capturing imagery instead of drawing it from scratch. Consumers will have new ways to capture and communicate their surroundings. And custom accessibility solutions can be installed for the disabled. This SBIR project has not only made contributions to basic research, but it has also developed real-world tools that haven't been available before now.
